Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: CollaborativE Multidisciplinary Investigations Through Undergraduate Research Experiences (CEMITURE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Georgia Southern University entitled CollaborativE Multidisciplinary Investigations Through Undergraduate Research Experiences (CEMITURE) that is led by Professors Karelle Aiken and Evans Afriyie-Gyawuwill. They will engage student participants in intensive research and professional development activities, which will allow for sustained growth as scientists. CEMITURE student participants will work directly with faculty mentors on their respective research projects in an environment where they develop the necessary skills and gain experiences that solidify their self-identities as scientists. The CEMITURE experience will be augmented by the active involvement of participants in educational, social and professional development activities, which will include training in scientific communication and workshops on career preparation, leadership, and ethics. The program is designed so that participants will build a community of scholars with their peers and GSU faculty; enhance their preparation for future success in graduate programs; endeavor to use their knowledge and expertise in science to make significant contributions to their own communities and the wider society; and gain a global perspective of STEM fields.

For ten weeks, the program, hosted by the Georgia Southern University (GSU) Chemistry Department, will engage undergraduate students in collaborative and multidisciplinary projects using analytical, material, organic, and bio-chemistry. Emphasis will be placed on recruiting students from institutions with limited research opportunities, particularly women, minorities, and students from rural and underserved areas of the southeastern United States. Projects will entail the design of new organic synthetic methodology for bioactive molecules; the development of materials with enhanced mechanical, thermal, and electrochemical properties; the design and probing of materials for their potential in the treatment of cancer and traumatic brain injury; the synthesis and investigation of novel organic molecules for detection of heavy transition metal cations; and the development of techniques for identification and quantification of organic and inorganic food contaminants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2014-2018 Georgia Southern University (GS) Chemistry and Biochemistry CollaborativE Multidisciplinary Investigations Through Undergraduate Research Experiences (CEMITURE) provided students with the skills, knowledge and tools to foster their development into highly engaged members of the science community. Over the four year period, the program served 27 scholars and surpassed goals in recruitment. CEMITURE scholars included women (78%), students from underrepresented races/ethnicities in STEM (33%), individuals from two- and four-year institutions (85%), first- and second-year students (63%) and persons from rural/urban cluster areas in the US (65%). Twenty-six out of the 27 participants were external to GS. Scholarly output during that period included 8 peer-reviewed publications and 35 conference presentations (33 where REU scholars presented their research, and 2 on managing an REU program by the Principal Investigator (PI) and Co-PI). The participants earned 11 awards for their presentations and abstracts during this period, and disseminated their research at national and/or regional symposia for the National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE), the Annual meeting of the Society of Toxicology (SOT), the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABCRMS), the Council on Undergraduate Research (CUR) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Symposium, the American Chemical Society (ACS) and the Southeastern Regional Meeting of the ACS (SERMACS).  

     The scholars’ research projects targeted traumatic injury, novel approaches to cancer therapy, ion-sensing, controlled drug-release, catalyst development, biocomposites for bone replacement, material design for lithium ion batteries, toxicological implications of meat-singeing practices in Ghana, understanding the bio-effects of nanomaterials, the development of organometallic systems for magnetic materials for data storage, and computational studies for aerospace applications. GS faculty who mentor undergraduates in productive research programs year-round, fully immersed the scholars in experiment design and the acquisition of fundamental techniques, ex. organic/nanomaterial/peptide synthesis, chemical analysis, cell culturing, biological sample-extractions and scientific computing. Participants also gained hands-on experience with instrumentation relevant to their projects.

     As a complement to their research experiences, scholars engaged in professional development activities designed to (1) equip them with the knowledge and skills for sustained progression in STEM and (2) provide exposure to tools commonly used by STEM professionals. Workshops covered safety, ethics, scientific literacy, graduate fellowships, career preparation, panel discussions with professionals in STEM and related fields, communication, and hands-on training with instrumentation. Notably and importantly, members of the discussion panels included GS and CEMITURE alumni. Through the communication workshops (SciPresent and SciWrite) participants constantly fine-tuned their oral and writing skills and received timely feedback from faculty and peers over the ten week period.

     There were also professional outings that aimed to widen students’ scope of STEM careers. These included tours of the Georgia Bureau of Investigation (GBI), Savannah, GA (2018), the Georgia Cancer Center (GCC), Augusta, GA (2016 & 2017), and the Herty Advanced Material Center, Savannah, GA (2015). With the GCC tour, students met PhD researchers and candidates who were tackling health issues alongside medical practitioners.

     Participants’ achievements over the 2015-2018 period included the attainment of Bachelor’s degrees (48%, others are continuing students); enrollment in PhD and Master’s programs; participation in summer internships following their CEMITURE experience; the pursuit of STEM-related, multi-year fellowships; outreach to provide instruction in Chemistry; and the attainment of awards for their research presentations (mentioned above).

     In recruitment, an emphasis was placed on first- and second-year students, underrepresented minorities in STEM, women, 2- and 4-year colleges, and the rural southeast. Posters, letters, and email solicitations were sent to 179 schools in 2015, and 238 in 2016/2017/2018. These included 40 Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU’s) and over 150 primarily undergraduate institutions (PUI’s), 2-/4-year colleges. CEMITURE mentors made recruitment visits to 5 of these Georgia PUI’s each fall for 2014-2016: Savannah State University (HBCU), East Georgia State College, College of Coastal Georgia, Brewton-Parker College, Fort Valley State University (HBCU), Georgia Perimeter College (2-yr. at the time of the visit) and the University of West Georgia. Fliers were distributed at NOBCChE and SERMACS meetings; information was disseminated by the Institute for Broadening Participation-Pathways to Science and CEMITURE sites. Applicants also reported finding information through NSF and ACS websites. Importantly, CEMITURE was recommended by past scholars. The overall result was a strong representation of women and applicants from rural/urban cluster areas and 2-/4-year colleges.

      CEMITURE mentors have excellent track records for guiding undergraduates in productive research and they are highly diverse in their backgrounds. The mentors for this funding cycle were from Brazil, China, Germany, Ghana, India, Jamaica, Trinidad & Tobago and the US. Significantly, 6 out the 14 research mentors that served in 2015-2018 were women, a strong representation that enhanced the quality of the program for all, especially CEMITURE’s female participants.

     CEMITURE scholars, at the time of participation in the program, had completed at least two science courses and were continuing-undergraduate students.
